projectDesc.p: "Copy of the riddle that was said to have been found in the temple of Saturn written on a golden tablet" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: نسخة اللغز الذي قيل انها وجدت في هيكل زحل مكتوبة في لوح ذهب
app.rdg: Copy of the riddle that was said to have been found in the temple of Saturn written on a golden tablet

app.lem: نقل حنين ابن اسحق وجده في الصحف القديمة
app.rdg: Translation of Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, who found it in ancient pages

app.lem: وتفسيرها للاب مار عمنويل مطران باجرمي
app.rdg: And a commentary on it by Father ʻAmanúʼél, metropolitan of Bét Garmay

app.lem: قال اذا ما صعد البخار الرطب من قعر البحر وانعقد في الجو سحابا هاطلا فجرت الاودية ولثقت الطرق واظلم نور الشمس والقمر فلم يعرف الليل من النهار وانقطعت السبل واغلقت ابواب المدينة ودعا كل ذي نفس الى ما اعد لنفسه.
app.rdg:
He said: When humid vapor rose from the depth of the sea and thickened in the air as clouds, coursing down so that the riverbeds flowed, the pathways were turned to mud, and the light of the sun and the moon grew dark, so night was not known from day, the roads were cut off, and the gates of the city were closed, and everyone with a soul called upon what they had prepared for themselves.
The Arabic word for “soul” (nafs) is used as a reflexive pronoun so “themselves” could be translated “their souls” and vice versa

app.lem: وخلا الملك في قبة فرشها الرياضي راكبا فرسا يحجبه جارية راكبة اسد.
app.rdg: And the king secluded himself in a dome furnished with gardens, riding a horse that he kept hidden like a slave woman riding a lion.

app.lem: واستدعا من وزيره ما رفعوا اليه اعوانه. واخذ من تدبير امره ومملكته.
app.rdg: He asked of his vizier what his servants had set before him, and was taken up with the administration of his affairs and his kingdom.

app.lem: فاستقر الامر عنده انه ان عاش مات وان مات عاش وان اهلك مملكته انحفظت نفسه وان حفظ اعوان مملكته هلكت نفسه.
app.rdg: Then it became fixed in his mind that if he lived he would die, and if he died he would live, and if he destroyed his kingdom, his soul would be saved, and if he saved the servants of his kingdom, his soul would be destroyed.

app.lem: فاثر الموت على الحياة وحفظ نفسه على مملكته ورعيته وفي تضاعيف فكره انقشع الغمام وطلع المنيران في القوس وقد كانا غابا في العقد الشمالي.
app.rdg:
So he preferred death over life, and saved himself rather than his kingdom and his subjects. Between the lines of his thought the clouds were scattered, and the two lights rose in Sagittarius after they had been hidden away in the northern node.
The "two lights" might reference the Sun and the Moon or possibly Jupiter and Saturn

app.lem: فتم الى الجند والرعية ما خامر قلب الملك فهما بالارتفاع به.
app.rdg: Then what had seized the heart of the king came to pass for the army and the subjects, so they were being wiped out by it.

app.lem: وفار التنور من الصنوبرة فارسل عليهم طوفان ريح وماء ولم يحدث شيا من غير شي فاجراه كالمد وعاش مستانسا بالوحدة.
app.rdg:
And water gushed forth from within the oven,
A reference to the story of Noah’s flood as found in the Qur’an (see Qur’an 11:40 and 23:27) so he sent upon them a typhoon of wind and water, and nothing came from nothing, so he made it flow as a flood. And he lived on in intimate acquaintance with his own solitude.

app.lem: فمن ضحك بكا ومن بكا ضحك.
app.rdg: So whoever laughed wept, and whoever wept laughed.

app.lem: والسلم على النفوس القريبة من مبديها. والرحمة على البعيدة لتلحق بها. والسبح لناظم الكل
app.rdg: Peace upon the souls that are close to their Creator, and mercy upon those far away so that they might catch up to them, and glory to the one who arranges all things.
The riddle has ended. The commentary follows.
